was founded in Victorian times by farmers who were concerned about the level of poverty that existed in the farming community.  In 2010 we will celebrate our 150th anniversary\r\n\r\nTimes may have changed but there is still hardship, especially for elderly or disabled people and families who struggle to make a living from the farm.  Each year, RABI makes payments totalling around £2million to help people facing financial difficulties.\r\n\r\nRABI supports elderly farmers and farm workers, and those of any age who are disabled, with regular grants or one-off payments for special items that they are unable to afford themselves.  Around £250,000 each year is paid out for disability aids and essential household appliances.\r\n\r\nWorking farming families who are facing hardship because of illness, bereavement or some other crisis can receive short-term help.  Just imagine you’re a dairy farmer, with cows to milk two or three times a day, but your young child is seriously ill in hospital.  Paying for help on the farm and even the cost of travel can soon mount up and cause financial difficulties.  That is when RABI can step in.\r\n\r\nWhen there is a crisis such as major flooding or outbreaks of animal disease, RABI makes emergency payments (over £900,000 in 2007 when there was an outbreak of foot and mouth) to help with domestic expenses."},"datatype":{"xmlns":"jg","text":"charity"},"pageShortName":{"xmlns":"jg","text":"/rabi"},"jgApiId":{"xmlns":"jg","text":"287"},"images":{"@xmlns:i":"http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance","xmlns":"jg","image":{"xmlns":"","size":"small","uri":"http://v3-sandbox.justgiving.com/Utils/imaging.ashx?width=120&height=120&square=120&imageType=charitybrandinglogo&img=rabi_logo3.jpg"}}},{"id":"charity-2313","title":{"type":"text","text":"The Thistle Foundation"},"updated":"2015-04-30T14:09:24+01:00","author":{"name":"The Thistle Foundation","uri":"http://www.justgiving.com","email":"no-contact@justgiving.com"},"link":{"rel":"alternate","href":"http://api-sandbox.justgiving.com/v1/charity/2313"},"content":{"type":"text","text":"We are a boundary-pushing, pioneering organisation helping bring about a society where everyone has the right to feel involved and empowered, regardless of their disabilities or health condition. Hospice"},"updated":"2015-04-30T14:09:24+01:00","author":{"name":"Highland Hospice","uri":"http://www.justgiving.com","email":"no-contact@justgiving.com"},"link":{"rel":"alternate","href":"http://api-sandbox.justgiving.com/v1/charity/2319"},"content":{"type":"text","text":"Highland Hospice is the only hospice serving adults with incurable life limiting disease in the Highlands of Scotland and is acknowledged as the centre of specialist palliative care expertise in the region. A full multidisciplinary team is employed to provide true holistic care and comprises medical and nursing staff, occupational, physio and complementary therapists, a chaplain and family support workers. The Hospice currently provides a 10 bed In Patient Unit in Inverness and a Day Hospice on the same site. The Hospice also provides bereavement counselling for relatives, a 24 hour telephone helpline and education and training for other healthcare professionals to enhance their ability to provide palliative care in their own communities. In Zambia, a large percentage (30-50%) of the population is infected by Malaria due to the high incidence of HIV (weakens the immune system), and water logging (provides perfect conditions for mosquito larvae). Further, children who contract malaria suffer from its effects over their entire lifetime. Our project will provide bed nets & education on prevention to 5000 children, and families","organisationCity":"San Diego","organisationCountry":"United States","organisationLogoUrl":"https:\/\/dpqe0zkrjo0ak.cloudfront.net\/pfil\/organ\/5119\/orglogo.jpg","organisationName":"Power of Love Foundation","organisationUrl":"http:\/\/www.poweroflove.org","progressUpdates":[{"authorName":"Alka Subramanian","content":"<p>With your support, Power of Love Foundation was able to provide 2000 long lasting insecticide treated nets and education on prevention of malaria to children and families in the summer of 2014. Recipients of nets included those sections of the population most vulnerable to malaria, namely children under five years of age, HIV positive children, expecting moms, people living with HIV, people infected with TB, and orphans and vulnerable children.<\/p>\u000a<p>In order to assess the impact of our malaria prevention program, we conducted a follow up study in October 2014. The study indicated that the use of bed nets has led to fewer cases of malaria in the community and fewer visits to the clinic. As a result of improved health, school attendance and performance in school is higher. We are confident that with the continued provision of malaria bed nets and education, there will be a marked reduction in the incidence of malaria in this community. More detail is provided below. &nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Findings of a Post-distribution of Malaria Nets Study<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>In order to understand the impact of the provision of nets and education on malaria prevention we met with 200 beneficiary families in October 2014 to:<\/p>\u000a<p>(i)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; assess the impact of nets usage,<\/p>\u000a<p>(ii)&nbsp;&nbsp; learn if nets were being used as demonstrated and identify and educate families who were not using nets in the proper way, &nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p>(iii)&nbsp;assess the number of malaria cases\/deaths if any,<\/p>\u000a<p>(iv)&nbsp;estimate the number of direct and indirect beneficiaries.<\/p>\u000a<p><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">Findings of the Study<\/span>: &nbsp;Based on our conversations we learnt that most beneficiaries,<\/p>\u000a<p>(i)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; know what measures to take to prevent malaria,<\/p>\u000a<p>(ii)&nbsp;&nbsp; are using the nets as demonstrated prior to the provision of nets,&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p>(iii)&nbsp;know when and where to take the nets for re-treating with pesticide after six months, &nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p>(iv)&nbsp;are storing nets properly as they are relatively clean and not damaged\/torn, and<\/p>\u000a<p>(v) the number of direct and indirect beneficiaries is approximately 3200 adults and children as a net can sleep multiple people (one net can sleep two adults or four young children).<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Impact of the Provision of Nets and Education on Malaria Prevention<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>Most of the older children and adult beneficiaries are using the bed nets, and the nets are being used as demonstrated during the distribution day activities. Nets were kept clean and stored properly when not in use. A few beneficiaries did not know the proper way of using nets and they were provided with information on this subject. In addition, recipients of nets have increased knowledge and awareness about malaria prevention.<\/p>\u000a<p>Community and Church leaders expressed their thanks and would like this malaria prevention program to continue in 2015 and beyond. This is especially true as most families live on less than one dollar a day due to high levels of unemployment and are unable to afford net. &nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p>The use of bed nets has led to fewer cases of malaria in the community and fewer visits to the clinic. As a result of improved health, school attendance and performance in school is higher. At this time we are rasing funds to provide 2000 bed nets in 2015. <strong>Please donate generously to save lives in Zambia.<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Rationale and Findings of a Post-distribution of Malaria Nets Study<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>In order to understand the impact of the provision of nets and education on malaria prevention we met with 200 beneficiary families in October 2014 to:&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<ul>\u000a<li>(i)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; assess the impact of nets usage,<\/li>\u000a<li>(ii)&nbsp;&nbsp; learn if nets were being used as demonstrated and identify and educate families who are not using nets in the proper way, &nbsp;<\/li>\u000a<li>(iii)&nbsp;assess the number of malaria cases\/deaths if any,<\/li>\u000a<li>(iv)&nbsp;estimate the number of direct and indirect beneficiaries.<\/li>\u000a<\/ul>\u000a<p>Findings of the Study: &nbsp;We met with more than 200 beneficiary families and learnt that most beneficiaries:<br \/>(i)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; know what measures to take to prevent malaria,<br \/>(ii)&nbsp;&nbsp; are using the nets and using them as demonstrated during the distribution day activities.&nbsp;<br \/>(iii)&nbsp;know when and where to take the nets for re-treating with pesticide after six months,&nbsp; and<br \/>(iv) are storing nets properly as they are relatively clean and not damaged\/torn.<\/p>\u000a<p>In addition, all children enrolled in Power of Love&rsquo;s paediatric HIV care program have been free of malaria since June 2014. As a result of their improved health (measured by a gain in weight and higher CD4 counts), school attendance and performance of these children has improved.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Impact of the Provision of Nets and Education on Malaria Prevention<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>Most of the older children and adult beneficiaries are using the bed nets, and the nets are being used as demonstrated during the distribution day activities. A few beneficiaries did not know the proper way of using nets and they were provided with information on this subject. In addition, beneficiaries have increased knowledge and awareness about malaria prevention. This is especially true as most families live on less than one dollar a day due to high levels of unemployment and are unable to afford net. &nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p>We are confident that with the continued provision of malaria bed nets and education, there will be a marked reduction in the incidence of malaria in this community.<\/p>\u000a<p>Thanks for helping prevent malaria in Zambia.&nbsp;<\/p>","datePublished":"\/Date(1417544310000+0000)\/","title":"Impact of Malaria Bed Nets on Children's Health in Zambia"},{"authorName":"Alka Subramanian","content":"<p><span>&ldquo;Thank You&rdquo; for supporting Power of Love Foundation&rsquo;s (POL) Project Mosquito Nets program. <strong>With your support, we were able to provide 2<\/strong><\/span><strong>000 long lasting insecticide treated nets to women and children vulnerable to malaria in Zambia in the summer of 2014. Your support will help keep approximately 8000 young children (as a net can sleep four young children) or 2000 families (two adults and two young children) malaria free and healthy.&nbsp;<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Profile of Beneficiaries: <\/strong>Beneficiaries<strong>&nbsp;<\/strong>were to 2000 families in the Matero compound in Lusaka, Zambia. This compound is one of the largest and most impoverished compounds in Lusaka with a population of 80,000-90,000. Many parts of Matero are water logged and have sewer ponds, leading to a high prevalence of malaria and hence a need for malaria prevention and education.<\/p>\u000a<p>Most beneficiaries were HIV positive children, children under the age of five, pregnant moms, women who are breast feeding and adults who are infected with TB and\/or HIV. These sections of the population are most vulnerable to malaria as their immune system is compromised, and because co-infection rates between malaria, HIV and TB are very high.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Distribution Activities<\/strong>: Children played traditional Zambian games while waiting for the distribution activities to begin. Distribution activities commenced with singing and dancing by the women and children present. This was followed by dances by children from St. John&rsquo;s Ambulance.<\/p>\u000a<p>The event was attended by the Church Pastor, Power of Love representatives and volunteers, community organizations, representatives from health clinics in Matero, and community members.<\/p>\u000a<p>Power of Love Foundation's Project Nurse commenced the health\/malaria education part of the day&rsquo;s activities by giving a short talk on hygiene and health. This was followed by education on malaria prevention and the proper use of nets by health care professional from local clinics. Highlights of the education on malaria prevention, (led by a Nurse from the government clinic) included:<\/p>\u000a<p>(i) proper use of mosquito nets, drainage maintenance, filling and removal of breeding sites, re-treating of mosquito nets,<\/p>\u000a<p>(ii) maintenance of nets (cleaning and storage)&nbsp;to prevent damage,<\/p>\u000a<p>(iii) negative impacts of malaria in pregnancy e.g. maternal death, abortion, still birth and low birth weight,<\/p>\u000a<p>(iv) information about malaria for HIV+ children,<\/p>\u000a<p>(v) identification of signs and symptoms of malaria, and&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p>(vi) proper storage of nets when not in use<\/p>\u000a<p>The Nurse explained that the best way to prevent malaria was to sleep under a net every night during malaria season. Her presentation was accompanied by a demonstration on the proper use and storage of nets. In addition, she underscored the importance of re-treating nets every six months, which could be done during the Child Health Weeks held in June and December each year. She informed the gathering that government clinics provide re-treatment kits free of cost. The Nurse also emphasized the need for keeping nets clean and stored properly.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Impact of the Distribution: <\/strong>Provision of bed nets and education on malaria prevention and proper use and maintenance of nets goes a long way in reducing the incidence of malaria from the community. As a result of past distributions, we are seeing fewer cases of malaria, increased knowledge about proper use and storage of nets, fewer visits to the hospital\/clinics, improved school attendance, and a higher quality of life and general well-being.&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Follow-Up Study<\/strong>: We will continue to conduct post-distribution follow-ups to assess the impact of nets on the incidence of malaria and on the health of beneficiary families. These follow-up studies provide us with information on the use of nets every night, proper storage and re-treatment, and health of the beneficiary families.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Need for Nets<\/strong>: Follow-up interviews with nets recipients indicates that the nets distributed over the last 2-3 years are in good condition and are being used as directed. However, we need several thousand more nets as a majority of households cannot afford to purchase a net and are vulnerable to malaria in our community.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Next Distribution of Nets<\/strong>: We will be providing an additional 2000 nets and education on malaria prevention before the onset of the malaria season in 2015.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Request for Funds<\/strong>: At this time we are raising funds to provide 1000 long lasting insecticide treated nets (LLIN&rsquo;s) in the Spring of 2015 and an additional 1000 nets in Fall 2015. Please donate generously as your donation will go a long way in preventing malaria and keeping the children healthy and in school.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Thanks for your dedication to prevent malaria in Zambia<\/strong>.<\/p>","datePublished":"\/Date(1413381674000+0100)\/","title":"Provision of Malaria Bed Nets and Education on Malaria Prevention in 2014"},{"authorName":"Alka Subramanian","content":"<p><span class=\"apple-style-span\"><strong><span>Introduction:<\/span><\/strong><span> Power of Love Foundation&rsquo;s, Project Mosquito Nets program provides long lasting insecticide treated bed nets to women and children vulnerable to malaria in Zambia. We would like to say a big &ldquo;Thank You&rdquo; to you for supporting this program. <strong>With your support, we were able to provide 1<\/strong><\/span><\/span><strong>000 insecticide treated nets to women and children vulnerable to malaria in Zambia in June 2014 and will&nbsp;<\/strong><strong>be providing an additional 1000 nets and education on malaria in August 2014.<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Profile of Beneficiaries: <\/strong>Nets were provided to 1000 families in the Matero compound in Lusaka, Zambia. This compound is one of the largest and poorest in Lusaka with a population of around 80,000-90,000. Many parts of Matero are water logged and have sewer ponds, leading to a high prevalence of malaria and hence the need for malaria prevention via nets. &nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p>In order to identify and distribute nets to the intended beneficiaries we worked with several community organizations such as Churches, government health clinics, and other representative organizations. Beneficiaries were HIV positive children, children under the age of five, pregnant women, women who are breast feeding, and adults who are infected with TB\/HIV. These sections of the population are most vulnerable to malaria as the immune system of people living with HIV is compromised, and because co-infection rates between malaria, HIV and TB are very high.&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Distribution Activities<\/strong>: A few children played traditional Zambian games while waiting for the distribution activities to begin. The distribution activities commenced with singing and dancing by the women and children present. This was followed by dances by school children from the community. Several local and Church leaders participated in the distribution activities. The event was attended by Mrs. Malumo sister in-charge of Matero main Clinic, Rev. Phaika from Presbyterian Church Matero Congregation, Mr. Simusosha from Ward Development committee (he is the chair person in charge of CBOs in Matero), Mrs. Nkazwe from the Lusaka City Council, and Power of Love representatives.<\/p>\u000a<p>Power of Love Foundation's, Project Nurse provided education on malaria prevention. He emphasized the importance of sleeping under a net every night as this is the most effective way to prevent malaria, and explained how to use and maintain (cleaning and storage) a&nbsp;net to prevent damage. In addition, he explained drainage and maintenance activities around the home, and filling and removal of breeding sites. Finally, he explained the importance of retreating nets every six months. This could be done during the Child Health Weeks held in June and December each year. The Nurse also underscored the need for keeping nets clean and stored properly. &nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p>This was followed by a demonstration on the proper use and maintenance of nets by a Nurse from one of the government clinics. She encouraged the participants to retreat the nets every few months and especially since the government clinics provide retreatment kits free of cost. Finally, the Nurse underscored the need for keeping nets clean and how to store them to prevent damage when not in use.&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Impact of the Distribution: <\/strong>Provision of bed nets and education on malaria prevention goes a long way in eradicating malaria from the community. As a result of past distributions, we are seeing very few cases of malaria among children in our paediatric HIV\/AIDS care program and a reduction in the incidence of malaria in our community. We will continue to conduct a post-distribution study to assess the impact of nets on the incidence of malaria and on the health of the beneficiary families. This study will assess: if the nets are being used every night, if the nets are being used and stored properly, if the nets are retreated every six months, and the health of the beneficiary families.<\/p>\u000a<p>We expect to see a marked reduction in the incidence of malaria and an increase in school attendance due to improved health of the children.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Need for Nets<\/strong>: Follow-up interviews with nets recipients indicates that nets distributed over the last 2-3 years, are in good condition and are being used as directed. However, we need several thousand more nets as a majority of households cannot afford to purchase a net and are without bed nets in our community and in Zambia.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Next Distribution of Nets<\/strong>: We will be providing an additional 1000 nets and education on malaria prevention in August 2014. &nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Request for Funds<\/strong>: At this time we are raising funds to provide 1000 long lasting insecticide treated nets (LLIN&rsquo;s) in the Spring of 2015 and an additional 1000 nets in Fall 2015. Please donate generously as your donation will go a long way in preventing malaria and keeping the children healthy and in school.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Thanks for your dedication to prevent malaria in Africa<\/strong>.&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;<\/p>","datePublished":"\/Date(1405515669000+0100)\/","title":"A Report on the Distribution of Long lasting Insecticide Treated Nets in Zambia"},{"authorName":"Alka Subramanian","content":"<p><strong><span>Happy Mother's Day! This Mother's day, give a gift of health to a family in Zambia. <\/span><\/strong><span>Our <\/span><a href=\"http:\/\/www.globalgiving.org\/projects\/project-mosquito-nets\/\"><span>malaria prevention<\/span><\/a><span> program provides long lasting insecticide treated bed nets and education on prevention of malaria to children and families vulnerable to malaria in Zambia. <\/span><span>Your ongoing support has helped in keeping children malaria free, healthy and in school.&nbsp;<\/span><\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Impact of Usage of Mosquito Bed Nets on Children's' Health<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>Over the last four years, we were able to provide 4800 long lasting insecticide treated nets and education on prevention of malaria to children and families in Zambia. These nets were used by an estimated 9600 children (as each net can sleep up to four young children) and 4800 adults (as each net can sleep two adults). Nets are provided to people who are vulnerable to malaria; for example, people living with HIV, older people, expecting moms, young children, and people with TB. Use of bed nets has led to a marked improvement in the health of all beneficiaries but the impact on the health of young children has been greater. This is because malaria can have severe consequences on the health of younger children whose bodies have yet to develop the strength to fight the disease. In addition, malaria can be fatal for a child who is malnourished and HIV positive. Also, bed nets can save lives of pregnant women as malaria can be fatal for a HIV positive pregnant women. Finally, people living with HIV are three times as likely to suffer from malaria, as compared to a person who is HIV negative.<\/p>\u000a<p><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">Need For Nets<\/span>: The need for several thousand more nets is ongoing for the following reasons: (i) in low income areas in Zambia, there are several water logged areas\/sewers which are breeding grounds for mosquitoes, (ii) due to an unemployment rate upwards of 67%, the residents of our community are not able to afford a net, and (iii) a high rate of HIV incidence increases their vulnerability to malaria.<\/p>\u000a<p>At this time we are raising funds to provide 2000 long lasting insecticide treated nets (LLIN&rsquo;s) before the start of the next malaria season in Zambia. Please <a href=\"http:\/\/www.globalgiving.org\/dy\/cart\/view\/gg.html?cmd=gcart&amp;event=scAdd&amp;synchronizerToken=-2410411-3104119-65-55-117-20258480-121-120-106-1102221-66\">donate <\/a>generously to help save lives. &nbsp;A donation of $10 will provide two nets that can prevent malaria for a family of two adults and 3-4 small children.<\/p>\u000a<p>Thanks for your support.&nbsp;<\/p>","datePublished":"\/Date(1399208468000+0100)\/","title":"Happy Mother's Day from our Zambian Families"},{"authorName":"Alka Subramanian","content":"<p>Power of Love Foundation&rsquo;s (POL) <a href=\"http:\/\/www.globalgiving.org\/projects\/project-mosquito-nets\/\">Project Mosquito Nets<\/a> program provides long lasting insecticide treated bed nets and education on prevention of malaria to women and children&nbsp;in Zambia. At the last distribution in September 2013, 1000 long lasting insecticide treated nets were distributed to 920 families. The beneficiaries included women and children, people living with HIV\/AIDS, TB patients, and pregnant mothers &ndash; segments of the population most vulnerable to malaria.<\/p>\u000a<p>In December 2013, we reached out to beneficiary families to assess the impact of nets usage and to learn if the nets were being used as demonstrated during distribution activities. Here is a summary of our findings:<\/p>\u000a<ol>\u000a<li>\u000a<p>The provision of 1000 nets benefitted 1476 people directly as each net was being shared by 2-3 small children or two adults.<\/p>\u000a<\/li>\u000a<li>\u000a<p>Out of the 1476 beneficiaries, only 31 people (24 children, and seven women) contracted malaria and were treated.<\/p>\u000a<\/li>\u000a<li>\u000a<p>As a result of the education on prevention of malaria and demonstrations prior to the distribution of nets, most beneficiaries (including older children) had increased knowledge of malaria, its signs and symptoms, how to prevent it, and about maintenance and usage of nets.<\/p>\u000a<\/li>\u000a<li>\u000a<p>Out of the 920 homes that were monitored, 116 households did not know that the nets can be re-treated every 6-12 months. In addition, 147 nets were mended as they were torn during use. These families have been educated on the proper use, maintenance, and re-treatment of nets.<\/p>\u000a<\/li>\u000a<li>\u000a<p>The health of all children has improved as seen by an improvement in their weight and CD4 counts. Out of the 200 HIV positive children in our <a href=\"http:\/\/www.poweroflove.org\/programs-children\">pediatric HIV\/AIDS care<\/a> program, 51showed an increase in their CD4 count and all (except three), maintained their weight and CD4 count.<\/p>\u000a<\/li>\u000a<li>\u000a<p>As a result of better health of the children, there was an improvement in school attendance and performance.<\/p>\u000a<\/li>\u000a<li>\u000a<p>We discovered that most of the nets had become dirty due to the smoke in the houses. The beneficiaries suggested that it would be better if the nets could be made in colors other than white in future. We have made a note and will send this suggestion to the supplier of our nets.&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<\/li>\u000a<\/ol>\u000a<p><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">Response of Beneficiary Families and Need for Nets<\/span>: Net recipients are very happy with the mosquito bed nets and they hope that the distribution activities continue in 2014 and beyond. They informed us that more nets are needed as there are several hundred households in their community who cannot afford to purchase a net and are sleeping without one in an area where the incidence of malaria is high.<\/p>\u000a<p><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">Request for Funds<\/span>: At this time we are raising funds to provide 2000 long lasting insecticide treated nets (LLIN&rsquo;s) in Spring 2014 and an additional 2000 nets in Fall 2014. Please donate generously as your donation will go a long way in preventing malaria and keeping the children healthy and in school.<\/p>\u000a<p>Thanks as always for your support and encouragement.<\/p>","datePublished":"\/Date(1393077686000+0000)\/","title":"Results of A Follow-Up Study for Nets Distributed in September 2013"},{"authorName":"Alka Subramanian","content":"<p>Power of Love Foundation&rsquo;s (POL) Project Mosquito Nets program provides long lasting insecticide treated bed nets to women and children vulnerable to malaria in Zambia. As you know we were able to provide 1000 long lasting nets to families vulnerable to malaria last September. In order to assess the impact of nets usage and to learn if the nets were being used as demonstrated during distribution activities, we interviewed a few families last week. Here is a summary of our findings:<\/p>\u000a<p>(i) Between September and December 15, 2013, only two children out of 200 children in our program contracted malaria.<\/p>\u000a<p><span style=\"line-height: 1.385;\">(ii) None of the adults in our program contracted malaria.<\/span><\/p>\u000a<p>(iii) Almost all beneficiary adults (approx. 96%) were knowledgeable about malaria prevention and were using the nets as demonstrated during the distribution activities. The recipients who were not aware about malaria prevention and proper use of nets were educated on these issues.<\/p>\u000a<p>(iv) The health of all children has improved\/stabilized as seen by an improvement in their weight and\/or CD4 counts.<\/p>\u000a<p>(v) There was an improvement in school attendance and performance.<\/p>\u000a<p>(vi) &nbsp;At the end of the conversation, our health care workers reminded the families to re-treat the nets after six months of use at the local clinic.<\/p>\u000a<p><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">Response of Beneficiary Families and Need for Nets<\/span><span style=\"line-height: 1.385;\">: Net recipients are very happy with the mosquito bed nets and they hope that the distribution activities continue in 2014 and beyond. They informed us that more nets are needed as there are several hundred households in their community who cannot afford to purchase a net and are sleeping without one in an area where the incidence of malaria is high.<\/span><\/p>\u000a<p><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">Request for Funds<\/span>: At this time we are raising funds to provide 2000 long lasting insecticide treated nets (LLIN&rsquo;s) in the Spring of 2014 and an additional 2000 nets in Fall 2014. Please <a href=\"http:\/\/www.globalgiving.org\/projects\/project-mosquito-nets\/\">donate <\/a>generously as your donation will go a long way in preventing malaria and keeping the children healthy and in school.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Happy holidays and thanks for keeping the Zambian children malaria free<\/strong>.<\/p>\u000a<p>&nbsp;<\/p>","datePublished":"\/Date(1388415668000+0000)\/","title":"Early Results of the Follow-Up Study on Nets Provided in September 2013"},{"authorName":"Alka Subramanian","content":"<p><span>Power of Love Foundation&rsquo;s&nbsp;<\/span><a href=\"http:\/\/www.globalgiving.org\/projects\/project-mosquito-nets\/\">Project Mosquito Nets<\/a><a href=\"http:\/\/www.globalgiving.org\/projects\/project-mosquito-nets\/\"> <\/a>program provides long lasting insecticide treated bed nets, <span>education on prevention of malaria and proper use and maintenance of nets<\/span>&nbsp;to families vulnerable to malaria in Zambia. We would like to say a big &ldquo;Thank You&rdquo; for supporting this program. Please take a moment and treat yourself to this<span>&nbsp;<\/span><a href=\"http:\/\/www.youtube.com\/watch?v=98b1wMC8cTo\">short video<span><span>&nbsp;<\/span><\/span><\/a>which was taken during our last field visit. The children had a lot of fun making origami birds and playing with them. We hope&nbsp;you enjoy the video as much as we do.&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p><span>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;<\/span><span style=\"font-size: xx-large;\"><a href=\"http:\/\/www.youtube.com\/watch?v=98b1wMC8cTo\">THANK YOU<\/a><\/span><span>&nbsp;<\/span><\/p>\u000a<p>Happy Holidays from the Power of Love Team<\/p>\u000a<p>&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p>&nbsp;<\/p>","datePublished":"\/Date(1386946868000+0000)\/","title":"A Big Thank You and Happy Holidays"},{"authorName":"Alka Subramanian","content":"<p>Power of Love Foundation&rsquo;s (POL) Project Mosquito Nets program provides long lasting insecticide treated bed nets to women and children vulnerable to malaria in Zambia. We would like to say a big &ldquo;Thank You&rdquo; to you for supporting this program. <strong>With your support, we were able to provide 1<\/strong><strong>000 insecticide treated nets to women and children vulnerable to malaria in Zambia in September 2013<\/strong>.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong style=\"line-height: 1.385;\">Profile of Beneficiaries: <\/strong><span style=\"line-height: 1.385;\">Nets<\/span><strong style=\"line-height: 1.385;\"> <\/strong><span style=\"line-height: 1.385;\">were provided to 1000 families in the Matero township in Lusaka, Zambia. The Matero Township is densely populated and most of areas are water logged and have sewer ponds. Due to the high prevalence of malaria in this area, we have been providing nets in Zambia since 2009. Beneficiaries of the nets were children and families in Power of Love&rsquo;s pediatric HIV\/IDS care program, women vulnerable to malaria in Power of Love&rsquo;s microloans program and vulnerable children who attend the safe park program and members of the community who are vulnerable to malaria. In order to reach the intended beneficiaries we involved several community organizations such as Churches, and government health clinics, to identify and distribute nets through their representatives.<\/span><\/p>\u000a<p>A list of the organizations\/beneficiaries with the number of nets provided is given below:<\/p>\u000a<ol>\u000a<li>Kapiri-Mposhi (a rural area in Zambia with a high incidence of malaria) &nbsp;&nbsp;300<\/li>\u000a<li>Children and families in our pediatric HIV\/AIDS care program &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 350<\/li>\u000a<li>Women in our micro loans program &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 80<\/li>\u000a<li>Families in the community of Matero (identified via Safe Park program) &nbsp; &nbsp;65<\/li>\u000a<li>Health Clinics (including Government Clinics) &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 85<\/li>\u000a<li>Local Churches&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; - &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;75<\/li>\u000a<li>Community Organizations (e.g. Matero Police, Kwasha Mukwenu) &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;45<\/li>\u000a<\/ol>\u000a<p><strong>Total&nbsp; <\/strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<strong>1000<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>Most of the beneficiaries were children who are HIV positive, children under the age of five years, pregnant moms, women who are breast feeding, and HIV positive children, and adults who are infected with TB. These sections of the population are most vulnerable to malaria as their immune system is compromised due to their HIV positive status, and because co-infection rates between malaria, HIV and TB are very high.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Distribution Activities<\/strong>: A few children played traditional Zambian games while waiting for the distribution activities to begin. Several local and Church leaders participated in the distribution activities. The distribution activities commenced with singing and dancing by the women and children present. This was followed by short plays about the benefits of using nets by teenage children. The area councilor for Lusaka, thanked the Matero Care Centre for organizing the event and the Power of Love Foundation and the Granny Connection for their support for this program. He said that he hoped that the provision of nets continues and thanked donors for supplementing the Goverments effort in the fight against malaria.A team from the Zambian National Broadcasting Corporation video taped the event for inclusion in the national news. A Nurse from one of the local clinics provided a demonstration on the proper use and maintenance of nets. She emphasized the need of using a mosquito net every night as was the best way to prevent malaria. She encouraged the participants to retreat the nets every few months and especially when the government clinics provide this retreatment kits free of cost. Finally, the Nurse underscored the need of keeping the nets clean and how to store them to prevent damage when not in use.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Impact of the Distribution: <\/strong>Provision of bed nets and education on malaria prevention and proper use and maintenance of nets goes a long way in eradicating malaria from the community. As a result of this distribution of nets, and proper use by beneficiaries we expect to see a marked reduction in the incidence of malaria and an increase in school attendance. Also, a post-distribution study will be conducted to assess the impact of the nets on the incidence of malaria and to determine if the nets are maintained (treated with insecticide) and used as required.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Need for Nets<\/strong>: Follow-up interviews with nets recipients indicates that the nets distributed over the last 2-3 years, are in good condition and are being used for malaria prevention by the beneficiary households. However, more nets are needed as there are several hundred households who cannot afford to purchase a net and are without bed nets in Zambia.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Request for Funds<\/strong>: At this time we are raising funds to provide 1000 long lasting insecticide treated nets (LLIN&rsquo;s) in the Spring of 2014 and an additional 1000 nets in Fall 2014. Please donate generously as your donation will go a long way in preventing malaria and keeping the children healthy and in school.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <strong>&nbsp;<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Thanks for your dedication to prevent malaria in Zambia.<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>&nbsp;<\/p>","datePublished":"\/Date(1382032868000+0100)\/","title":"A Report on the Distribution of Treated Mosquito Nets in Zambia"},{"authorName":"Alka Subramanian","content":"<p>Power of Love Foundation&rsquo;s (POL) Project Mosquito Nets program provides long lasting insecticide treated nets to women and children vulnerable to Malaria in Zambia. Segments of the population that are particularly vulnerable to malaria and for whom malaria could be fatal include: children under five years, older people, pregnant women, people living with HIV, and people who have TB. Children and adults who have HIV\/AIDS are more likely to experience severe malaria requiring hospitalization and the risk of death. An added complication is that co-infection rates between HIV, malaria, and TB are high.&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Impact of Usage of Malaria Bed Nets on Children's' Health<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>Over the last three years, we were able to provide 3800 long lasting insecticide treated nets and education on prevention of malaria to children and families vulnerable to malaria in Zambia. This is because malaria can have severe health consequences on the health of younger children whose bodies have yet to develop the strength to fight the disease. In addition, malaria can be fatal for a child who is malnourished and HIV positive. Also, the use of bed nets has prevented pregnant women from contracting malaria in our community. The nets were used by an estimated 4000 children (as each net can sleep up to four young children) and 2500 adults (as each net can sleep two adults). Usage of the mosquito bed nets has led to a marked improvement in the health of all beneficiaries but the impact on the health of young children has been much greater. This is because malaria can have severe health consequences on the health of younger children whose bodies have yet to develop the strength to fight the disease. In addition, malaria can be fatal for a child who is malnourished and HIV positive. Also, the use of bed nets has prevented pregnant women from contracting malaria in our community. This is very encouraging as malaria can be fatal for HIV positive pregnant women. Finally, people living with HIV are three times as likely to suffer from malaria, as compared to a person who is HIV negative.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Need For Nets<\/strong>: The need for several thousand more nets is ongoing for the following reasons: (i) in low income areas in Zambia, there are several water logged areas\/sewers which are breeding grounds of mosquitoes, (ii) due to an unemployment rate upwards of 67%, the residents of the community are not able to afford a net, and (iii) a high rate of HIV incidence increases their vulnerability to malaria.<\/p>\u000a<p>At this time we are raising funds to provide 1000 long lasting insecticide treated nets (LLIN&rsquo;s) before the start of the next malaria season in Zambia. Please <a href=\"http:\/\/poweroflove.org\/donate\">donate<\/a> generously to &nbsp;help save lives. To learn more&nbsp;about our malaria prevention program in Zambia <a href=\"http:\/\/poweroflove.org\/stories-children-who-are-malaria-free-and-school-result-sleeping-under-net\">click here.<\/a>&nbsp; <strong>&nbsp;<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Thanks again for your continued support for this program.<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>&nbsp;<\/p>","datePublished":"\/Date(1368198069000+0100)\/","title":"Mosquito Bed Nets and Children's Health in Zambia"},{"authorName":"Alka Subramanian","content":"<p>Project Mosquito Nets provides education on prevention of malaria and long lasting insecticide treated nets to children and families vulnerable to malaria in Zambia. Segments of the population that are particularly vulnerable to malaria and for whom malaria could be fatal include: children under five years, older people, pregnant women, people living with HIV, and people who have TB. Children and adults who have HIV\/AIDS are more likely to experience severe malaria requiring hospitalization and the risk of death. An added complication is that co-infection rates between HIV, malaria, and TB are high. &nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p>Over the last few years we have seen that as a result of sleeping under a net, the incidence of malaria has been reduced, and school attendance has increased due to improved health of the children. For a short video on the distribution day activities <a href=\"http:\/\/www.youtube.com\/watch?v=1DDMPH3KOS8\">click here<\/a>. To learn more&nbsp;about our malaria prevention program in Zambia <a href=\"http:\/\/poweroflove.org\/distribution-1000-nets-zambia-september-2012\">click here.<\/a> &nbsp;Given below are stories of two children who have been successful in preventing malaria, are attending school and are living close to normal lives.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Nelly: <\/strong>Nelly is a 10 year old HIV positive fourth grader. She lives with her grandmother in a household with 14 people as she lost her parents to AIDS. Nelly's grandmother received a long lasting insecticide treated net last September and since then both Nelly and her grandmother have been sleeping under a net. As a result, Nelly has been malaria free and is attending school regularly. We hope to provide nets to all members in Nelly's household at the next distribution.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Grace:&nbsp; <\/strong>Grace is 13 years old, HIV positive and is on ARV medication. She takes her medication regularly and on time as she understands the importance of adhering to the medication regimen.&nbsp; Grace is a bright young girl who loves school and all her classes. Her parents (also HIV positive) received nets from our program and since then the three of them have been malaria free. Since, Grace's family is HIV positive they are at increased risk of malaria (as their immune system is compromised) and the protection provided by anti-malarial treatment is also lower. Grace and her parents are grateful for the nets and for the existence of Project Mosquito Nets in their neighborhood.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Need For Nets<\/strong>: The need for several thousand more nets is ongoing for the following reasons:<\/p>\u000a<p>(i) In areas like Chunga and Zingaluma there are several water logged areas\/sewers which are breeding grounds of mosquitoes.<\/p>\u000a<p>(ii) Due to an unemployment rate upwards of 67%, the residents of the community are not able to afford a net. In addition, a high rate of HIV incidence increases their vulnerability to malaria.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Request for Funds<\/strong>: At this time we are raising funds to provide 2000 long lasting insecticide treated nets (LLIN&rsquo;s) in fall 2013. Please donate generously as your donation will go a long way in preventing malaria and keeping the children healthy and in school.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>The recipients of nets hope that this program continues in 2013 and beyond and would like us to convey their thanks to donors.<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Thanks as always for your support for this program.<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>&nbsp;<\/p>","datePublished":"\/Date(1363878067000+0000)\/","title":"Stories of children who are Malaria Free and in School as a result of Sleeping under a Net"},{"authorName":"Alka Subramanian","content":"<p><strong>Conversations with Beneficiaries of Malaria Nets Distributed in September 2012 - Part 2<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>Since the last distribution of 1000 long lasting insecticide treated nets in September 2012, we have been in contact with the recipients of nets and have had several conversation with them so that we can increase the effectiveness of our malaria prevention program in Zambia. For a short video on the distribution day activities <a href=\"http:\/\/www.youtube.com\/watch?v=1DDMPH3KOS8\">click here<\/a>.&nbsp;To learn more&nbsp;about our malaria prevention program in Zambia <a title=\"click here\" href=\"http:\/\/poweroflove.org\/distribution-1000-nets-zambia-september-2012\" target=\"_blank\">click here.<\/a>&nbsp;A summary of our continuing dialogue with beneficiaries of nets is given below.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Information gathered from beneficiaries of nets: <\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>In Jan 2013, our Project Nurse and health care workers, had conversation with 54 beneficiaries who received nets in September 2012. In addition, to the information provided in our last report, we learnt that:<\/p>\u000a<p>1. A net is large enough that four children under five years of age or 2 adults can sleep under it. This implies that two nets are effective in preventing malaria for six people in the household and hence the most effective use of donor funds.&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p>2. The use of mosquito nets has reduced the incidence of malaria in the community of Matero. This has been attributed to the use of nets and the spraying of insecticides in the water logged areas by the local government agencies. The biggest impact of the use of nets has been on the improved health of young children. Malaria can have severe health consequences on the health of a young child - a poor diet and a positive status aggravates the problem .<\/p>\u000a<p>3. The provision of mosquito nets has led to an increase in school attendance. Almost all families confirmed that their children's health had improved significantly after sleeping under a net.<\/p>\u000a<p>4. We were happy to learn that between June and December 2012, there were no reported cases of malaria amongst pregnant women in the community of Matero. This is very encouraging as malaria can be fatal for HIV positive pregnant women.<\/p>\u000a<p>5. People living with HIV are three times as likely to suffer from malaria, as compared to a person who is HIV negative. The use of bed nets and ARV medication has gone a long way in prolonging the life span of HIV positive children and adults. The results for people with TB are similar. &nbsp;&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Challenges Faced<\/strong>:&nbsp;Some of the challenges faced in the field are:<\/p>\u000a<p>(i) Recipients of nets have enough information on the use of the nets but they have limited space as the same room is used as a bedroom during the night and a sitting room during the day. This implies that they have to hang the net before sleeping every night and remove it the next day.<\/p>\u000a<p>(ii) Some of the nets are being used to keep away flies during the day.<\/p>\u000a<p>(iii) Most beneficiaries wash the nets with normal washing powder when the nets get dirty and do not re-treat them with insecticide after washing. We are continuing to educate the people on the proper maintenance, washing and recommended frequency for re-treatment with insecticide.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Need For Nets<\/strong>: The need for nets for several thousand more nets is ongoing for the following reasons:<\/p>\u000a<p>(i) In areas like Chunga and Zingaluma there are several water logged areas\/sewers which are breeding grounds of mosquitoes.<\/p>\u000a<p>(ii) Due to an unemployment rate upwards of 67%, the residents of the community are not able to afford a net. In addition, a high rate of HIV incidence increases their vulnerability to malaria.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Request for Funds<\/strong>: At this time we are raising funds to provide 1000 long lasting insecticide treated nets (LLIN&rsquo;s) in the spring of 2013 and an additional 1000 nets in fall 2013. Please donate generously as your donation will go a long way in preventing malaria and keeping the children healthy and in school.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>To Sum<\/strong>: All beneficiaries interviewed are happy with the receipt of nets, and the activities organized on distribution day like demonstration of the proper use, maintenance, and re-treatment of nets. In addition, we provide ongoing health education during home visits. The recipients of nets hope that this program continues in 2013 and beyond and would like us to convey their thanks to donors.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Thanks again for your support for this program.<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>&nbsp;<\/p>","datePublished":"\/Date(1360249268000+0000)\/","title":"Conversations with Beneficiaries of Malaria Nets"},{"authorName":"Alka Subramanian","content":"<p><strong>&nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Conversations with Beneficiaries of Malaria Nets Distributed in September 2012<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p><strong>We would like to wish our friends and supporters a Very Happy and Peaceful New Year.<\/strong><strong>&nbsp;&nbsp;<\/strong>With encouragement and support from you, Project Mosqutio Nets continues to provide education on prevention of malaria and long lasting insecticide treated nets to families vulnerable to malaria in Zambia. To learn more&nbsp;<a href=\"http:\/\/poweroflove.org\/distribution-1000-nets-zambia-september-2012\">click here.<\/a><\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Impact of the Distribution of Nets in September: <\/strong><strong>T<\/strong>hree months after the nets were distributed our Project Nurse had conversations with several families regarding the impact of the nets on their household. Here is what we learnt.<\/p>\u000a<p>1. Most of the families who received nets live in areas which are densely populated, have a high incidence of HIV\/AIDS, and have areas that are breeding grounds for mosquitoes due to standing water (such as the George compound, Chungwa and Chingwere areas).<\/p>\u000a<p>2. The average household size is about 8-9 people and they share 1-2 rooms and a small kitchen area. Since space is limited one of the challenges is to store the nets properly during the day as the sleeping area is used as a living room during the day. This means that they hang the nets at night but then have to take them down every morning.<\/p>\u000a<p>3. On average 2-3 people are sleeping under one net. This implies that one net can prevent malaria 2-3 people.<\/p>\u000a<p>4. All of the families we chatted with have been malaria free since they received the nets as they are using and maintaining the nets as demonstrated during the distribution event.<\/p>\u000a<p>5<strong>. <\/strong>The nets have prolonged the life span of HIV positive children and adults, as people living with HIV are three times as likely to suffer from malaria, as compared to a person who is HIV negative. In addition, malaria can be fatal in cases of women who are expecting a child and are HIV positive.<\/p>\u000a<p>6. All the beneficiaries interviewed are happy with the receipt of nets, hope that this program continues in 2013 and beyond and would like us to convey their thanks to donors.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>To Sum:<\/strong> The program has been received with a lot of enthusiasm in Matero compound in Lusaka, Zambia. This is proven by the fact that there is huge crowd on the day of the distribution and we have to take the help of the local police to maintain peace and order during the distribution activities. Provision of bed nets and education on malaria prevention and proper use and maintenance of nets goes a long way in eradicating malaria from the community. As a result of this distribution of nets, and proper use by beneficiaries we are seeing a marked reduction in the incidence of malaria and an increase in school attendance. However, several thousand more nets are needed as there are several thousand households without bed nets in Zambia.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Request for Funds<\/strong>: At this time we are raising funds to provide 1000 long lasting insecticide treated nets (LLIN&rsquo;s) in the Spring of 2013 and an additional 1000 nets in Fall 2013. Please donate generously as your donation will go a long way in preventing malaria and keeping the children healthy and in school.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p>Thanks for your support and encouragement.<\/p>\u000a<p>&nbsp;<\/p>","datePublished":"\/Date(1356706867000+0000)\/","title":"Conversations with Beneficiaries of Malaria Nets"},{"authorName":"Alka Subramanian","content":"<p><strong>Distribution of 1000 Mosquito Bed Nets in Zambia in September 2012<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>Power of Love Foundation&rsquo;s (POL) Project Mosquito   Nets program provides long lasting insecticide treated bed nets to women and   children vulnerable to Malaria in Zambia. We would like to say a big &ldquo;Thank   You&rdquo; to you for supporting this program. <strong>With   your support, we were able to provide 1<\/strong><strong>000 insecticide treated nets to women and children vulnerable to   Malaria in Zambia in September 2012<\/strong>. The distribution activities included   a demonstration regarding the proper use, treatment and maintenance of nets,   and education on prevention   of malaria. The event was attended by community partners, the area   councillor, and local leaders.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Profile of Beneficiaries: <\/strong>Nets<strong> <\/strong>were provided to 1000 families vulnerable to malaria. Most of the   beneficiaries were children who are HIV positive, children under the age of   five years, pregnant moms, women who are breast feeding, HIV positive   children, and adults who are infected with TB. These sections of the   population are most vulnerable to malaria as their immune system is   compromised due to their HIV positive status, and because co-infection rates   between malaria, HIV and TB are very high. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Impact of the Distribution: <\/strong>Provision of bed   nets and education on malaria prevention and proper use and maintenance of   nets goes a long way in eradicating malaria from the community. As a result   of this distribution of nets, and proper use by beneficiaries we expect to   see a marked reduction in the incidence of malaria and an increase in school   attendance. Also, a post-distribution study will be conducted to assess the   impact of the nets on the incidence of malaria and to determine if the nets   are maintained (treated with insecticide) and used as required.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Need for Nets<\/strong>: Follow-up   interviews with nets recipients indicates that the nets distributed over the   last 2-3 years, are in good condition and are being used for malaria   prevention by the beneficiary households. However, more nets are needed as   there are several thousand households without bed nets in Zambia.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Request for Funds<\/strong>: At this time   we are raising funds to provide 1000 long lasting insecticide treated nets   (LLIN&rsquo;s) in the Spring of 2013 and an additional 1000 nets in Fall 2013. We would like to say a big &ldquo;Thank You&rdquo; to you for supporting this program. With your support, &nbsp;we were able to provide 2000 insecticide treated nets to women and children vulnerable to Malaria in Zambia in 2011. For a detailed report of the distribution activities please visit <a href=\"http:\/\/poweroflove.org\/project-mosquito-nets-launched-rural-zambia\">http:\/\/poweroflove.org\/project-mosquito-nets-launched-rural-zambia<\/a>.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Next Distribution of Nets: In fall   2012, we will be distributing 1000 long lasting insecticide treated nets to women   and children vulnerable to malaria.<\/strong> The distribution activities will   include a demonstration regarding the proper use, treatment and maintenance   of nets, and education on malaria   prevention.<\/p>\u000a<p>&nbsp;<strong>Impact of the Distribution: <\/strong>Provision of bed   nets and education on malaria prevention and proper use and maintenance of   nets goes a long way in eradicating malaria from the community. Please   donate generously as your donation will go a long way in preventing malaria   and keeping the children healthy and in school.&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;<strong>&nbsp;<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>Thanks for your support and encouragement.<\/p>\u000a<p>&nbsp;<\/p>","datePublished":"\/Date(1344015488000+0100)\/","title":"Project Mosquito Nets - Next Distribution of Nets in Fall 2012"},{"authorName":"Alka Subramanian","content":"<p><strong>Results of a Post-distrbution Study for Nets Distrbuted in Rural Zambia in October 2010<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Introduction<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>We would like to thank our friends who have supported Project Mosquito Nets which provides education on malaria prevention and long lasting insecticide treated nets to women and children vulnerable to malaria in Zambia. This report discusses briefly the results of a post-distribution survey for distrbution of nets in rural area in Zambia in October 2010. For a detailed report of the distribution activities please visit <a href=\"http:\/\/poweroflove.org\/project-mosquito-nets-launched-rural-zambia\">http:\/\/poweroflove.org\/project-mosquito-nets-launched-rural-zambia<\/a>.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Post Distribution Survey Results<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>A post distribution survey was carried out in April 2012, approximately 18 months after the original distribution in October 2010. The survey was administered to 100 beneficiary households in the Ndeke compound in Kapiri-Mposhi, Zambia. The goal of this study was to assess the mosquito net usage, condition of the nets distrbuted, and the need for nets in this community<strong>. <\/strong>Based on the survey results we were able to draw the following conclusions:<\/p>\u000a<ol>\u000a<li>Most of the beneficiaries are using the nets correctly with a few not using them in the proper fashion. Recipients of nets who were not using them in the correct manner were advised on the correct usage of the nets at the time of this survey.<\/li>\u000a<li>The condition of the nets in the sampled houses was mostly very good. A few recipients reported that the nets were in a poor condition and this could be due to the fact that the nets were used over spring or metal beds. &nbsp;In a few cases, rats had made holes in the nets. In two households it was reported that the nets received were stolen.<\/li>\u000a<li>The&nbsp;usage of nets is 98%.<\/li>\u000a<li>The average number of people sleeping under one net is a little over 2. This implies that one net is helping prevent malaria for two people. We are happy with this result as this reduces the cost of malaria prevention.&nbsp;<\/li>\u000a<li>Need&nbsp;for nets - The number of nets received per household is lower than the number of sleeping places in each household. Most households have 3-5 sleeping spaces, but received only one or two nets. This implies that the community will benefit from additional nets for each household. &nbsp;<\/li>\u000a<\/ol>\u000a<p><strong>Conclusion<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>The nets distributed in   Kapiri-Mposhi, Zambia are in good condition and are being used for malaria   prevention by the beneficiary households. The distribution of these nets has gone   a long way in educating community members about malaria prevention, and reducing   the incidence of malaria in the community. Since, the last distribution was   successful and the need for nets is huge, we are raising funds at this time   for another distribution in September 2012.<\/p>\u000a<p>Thanks again for your   support.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>&nbsp;<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>&nbsp;<\/p>","datePublished":"\/Date(1336496403000+0100)\/","title":"Results of a Post-distribution Study"},{"authorName":"Alka Subramanian","content":"<p><strong>An Update on Project Mosquito Nets - Nets Distribution in Zambia in 2011<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>Power of Love Foundation&rsquo;s (POL) Project Mosquito Nets (PMN) program provides long lasting insecticide treated bed nets to women and children vulnerable to Malaria in Zambia. Power of Love&rsquo;s PMN was launched in Zambia in April 2010. To date more than 3800&nbsp;long lasting mosquito nets have been distributed in one urban are and one rural area in Zambia. We would like to sincerely thank donors who continue to support this program. It is with your support that we were able to <strong>provide <\/strong><strong>1000 insecticide treated nets to women and children vulnerable to Malaria in and around Lusaka, Zambia in October 2011.<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Distribution of Nets in Zambia<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>Recipients were identified through community outreach, including door-to-door home visits and were chosen based on need. For example, households with children under the age of 15 years living with unemployed grandparents, children of parents who were unemployed or too poor to purchase nets, and children of HIV positive parents. Each beneficiary household was given one net with the understanding that the net will be used by 1-3 family members.<\/p>\u000a<p><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">Location of the Distribution of Nets <\/span><\/p>\u000a<p>1. Site: Kapiri-Mposhi, Zambia. Nets Distributed: 700<\/p>\u000a<p>The majority of the nets were distributed to residents of the Ndeke compound in Kapiri-Mposhi, Zambia. Kapiri-Mposhi is a town of 75,000 residents located approximately 220 km away from Lusaka. The Power of Love Foundation partnered with &ldquo;Shalom Project&rdquo; (a local non-profit organization) to identify beneficiaries and complete distribution activities. The need for nets is huge in the Ndeke compound of Kapiri-Mposhi as most of its residents are unemployed and too poor to afford bed nets. In the rainy season in particular, this area becomes waterlogged and swampy creating an ideal breeding ground for mosquitos. In addition, Kapiri has high rates of HIV infection as it is the transport link for Tanzania.<\/p>\u000a<p>In 2010, Power of Love had distributed 1200 insecticide treated nets to the residents of Ndeke compound and one net was being used by 2-3 people on average. We are seeing a reduction in malaria cases as a result of the provision of nets in 2010 and in 2011. The Table below gives the number of malaria cases for the period, May to September for 2010 and 2011. This data was collected from the local clinic and shows a drop of 26% in the number of malaria cases in 2011.<\/p>\u000a<p><strong>Table 1 &ndash; Number of Malaria Cases in Ndeke, Kapiri-Mposhi for the months of May to September for 2010 and 2011.<\/strong><\/p>\u000a<p>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
